item.title: ÂØπ‰∫éÊ≥®ÂÜåÂÆòCraig OliveÂèäÂÖ∂ÂÆ∂‰∫∫Êù•ËØ¥ÔºåÈòøÂ∞îËå®Êµ∑ÈªòÊ∞èÁóá‰∏¥ËøëÂÆ∂Â∫≠- JoCoÊä•Âëä
item.description:
November is Alzheimer‚Äôs Awareness Month

JOHNSTON COUNTY ‚Äì For Johnston County Registrar of Deeds Craig Olive and his blended family, Alzheimer‚Äôs disease is personal. He and his kin have seen the disease ravage parents, siblings, grandparents, aunts and uncles.

Olive lost his mother, Pearl Thompson Brown Olive, to Alzheimer‚Äôs in 2007.

‚ÄúShe helped raise 15 children altogether ‚Äî stepchildren and her own,‚Äù he recalls in an interview from his office in the Johnston County Courthouse.

But Pearl was more than his mom.

‚ÄúAt age 45, she went back to school and got her nursing degree at what was then Johnston Technical College,‚Äù Olive says. ‚ÄúShe then worked 16 years as a nurse at WakeMed.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got a scholarship in her name at the college,‚Äù a proud Olive adds. ‚ÄúAnd they even named a room after her.‚Äù

But in her early 70s, Alzheimer‚Äôs began robbing him of the mother and woman he knew. She did and said inexplicable things, Olive says.

‚ÄúShe put utensils in the trashcan,‚Äù he recalls. ‚ÄúShe walked out into the median of Highway 70. She‚Äôd say she had to go pick my brother up from work, something she hadn‚Äôt had to do in years.‚Äù

His mother had been a regular at what was then the Clayton Senior Center, now the Clayton Center for Active Aging. ‚ÄúBut we had to stop that,‚Äù Olive says, explaining that his mother became too much for staff to handle. ‚ÄúMama was wandering around, even going into the men‚Äôs bathroom by mistake.‚Äù

Olive became his mother‚Äôs caregiver, but he had help. ‚ÄúMy mother was going to an adult day care program over here at First Baptist Church and then at Divine Destiny, another adult day care,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThat was a big help for me.‚Äù

But then his mother suffered a brain bleed in a fall, and Olive had to keep her at home. ‚ÄúShe was never like she had been before,‚Äù he says.

After his mother‚Äôs fall, Olive turned to in-home care for help, and he sang the praises of those caregivers, including Martha Godwin. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs like family,‚Äù he says all these years later. ‚ÄúShe was a jewel, and Camille Hunter too.‚Äù

For those who can afford it, Olive recommends in-home care. ‚ÄúI have nothing against nursing homes,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI just wish they had more staff members.‚Äù

For caregivers, Olive recommends self-care. ‚ÄúYou need to allow time for yourself,‚Äù he says, ‚Äúbecause it can take a toll. You‚Äôre under stress, worrying all the time.‚Äù

Caregivers can find themselves sacrificing things that gave them joy, adds Olive, who most recently found himself caring for a brother who died earlier this year of kidney disease.

‚ÄúI love the beach, and I haven‚Äôt been to the beach in four years because of being a caregiver,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúYou need to get away from the whole situation and give yourself time to do things,‚Äù Olive says.

And by all means, take advantage of the resources available, he says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a long, lonely, hard road,‚Äù Olive says of Alzheimer‚Äôs caregiving.

For help and advice, he turned to his mother‚Äôs doctors, Community & Senior Services of Johnston County, the state‚Äôs Division of Aging, the Johnston County Department of Social Services and the N.C. Alzheimer‚Äôs Association.

‚ÄúIt made the journey a lot easier,‚Äù Olive says.

A daughter‚Äôs story
Early on, Melanie Nunn and her siblings thought their mother, Brenda Ann Brown Dixon, was suffering from hearing loss.

‚ÄúConversations over the telephone became different and shorter than usual,‚Äù recalls Nunn, niece of Johnston County Registrar of Deeds Craig Olive. ‚ÄúWe even pursued getting her hearing aids, but they didn‚Äôt help.‚Äù

But the family was also aware that a far worse diagnosis was possible. ‚ÄúWe knew fairly early that mom had the possibility of developing dementia as I talked her into getting an APO-E blood test,‚Äù Nunn says.

The test determines a person‚Äôs genetic risk for Alzheimer‚Äôs.

‚ÄúHer result came back as a 3/4,‚Äù Nunn says. ‚ÄúThis meant mom was most likely going to develop dementia.‚Äù

And her mom‚Äôs doctor confirmed an early diagnosis of mild cognitive impairment.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm thankful for the blood test and knowing early that mom had a high probability of developing dementia,‚Äù Nunn says. ‚ÄúThis allowed us to prepare as much as we could and to really cherish our time together while she still had some clarity of mind.‚Äù

Because the diagnosis was early, her mom was able to remain at home, where Nunn‚Äôs dad was her main caregiver.

‚ÄúSince I lived close by, I gave dad breaks a few times a week for a few hours,‚Äù Nunn says. ‚ÄúI would wash and style mom‚Äôs hair and make sure she got a good bath and her hygiene was taken care of.‚Äù

Her mom found it hard to decide which outfit to wear each day. ‚ÄúSo we went through her closet and paired outfits ‚Äî tops with pants were hung together ‚Äî and narrowed her choices to five,‚Äù Nunn says. ‚ÄúThis helped her and my dad immensely.‚Äù

Her father needed more help than he admitted. ‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt want us to worry,‚Äù Nunn says. ‚ÄúMom had always done the laundry, cooking, house cleaning, etc. He really tried, but meals became pickups from restaurants.‚Äù

As the disease progressed, her mother changed. ‚ÄúMom started having bathroom accidents and asking repetitive questions,‚Äù Nunn says.

Her personality changed too. ‚ÄúShe was initially an introvert but became more of an extrovert who spoke her mind in love,‚Äù says Nunn, who also changed. ‚ÄúI became a fierce protector and advocate for my mom.‚Äù

And when her father died in 2020, Nunn became her mother‚Äôs chief caregiver. ‚ÄúMom came to live with my family and I for 16 months, until she needed more care than I could give her,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt able to care for her full time, care for two kids at home, homeschool them and be a full-time wife.‚Äù

Putting her mom in a skilled nursing home was hard but necessary, Nunn says. ‚ÄúI experienced so much guilt but knew that placing her in a facility where she would have access to therapy would be helpful,‚Äù she says.

In a real sense, the daughter became the mother in terms of care. ‚ÄúBut the respect I had for her as my mom never dwindled,‚Äù Nunn says.

‚ÄúDuring her time with dementia, the Lord taught me so much through her,‚Äù she adds. ‚ÄúMom handled the declines that came with dementia with such grace.‚Äù

Still, the woman and mother she knew slipped away. ‚ÄúI truly missed opportunities to have meaningful conversations with my mom,‚Äù Nunn says.

As she cared for her mom amid her decline, Nunn found comfort in daily walks ‚Äî ‚Äúa great way to relieve stress,‚Äù she says ‚Äî and in her faith. ‚ÄúI talked to God and read the Bible daily,‚Äù Nunn says.

‚ÄúI knew I needed his strength and I couldn‚Äôt be all that mom needed me to be without him.‚Äù

Nunn also took part in online grief counseling. ‚ÄúI started this after my dad passed away and I began caring for mom,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI had godly friends from my church who prayed for me, listened to me and helped me care for mom to give me a break.‚Äù

Nunn is grateful too for the support she received from her husband and children. ‚ÄúMy husband treated and loved my mom like his own,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúHe also took over household chores so I could spend time with mom. He was my eyes and kept me accountable to eat well, continue to exercise and seek out help when I needed it.‚Äù

Caring for someone with Alzheimer‚Äôs is a labor of love, Nunn says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard and emotional, but so worth it,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúCherish every day.‚Äù

Nunn has this advice for caregivers of dementia sufferers. ‚ÄúMake life as normal as possible for them because change is hard for someone with dementia,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúHug them and express your love to them. They can still hear and feel.‚Äù

In the nursing home, Nunn decorated her mom‚Äôs room much like her room back home.

‚ÄúI took her to get her nails done, kept her dressed in the best clothes ‚Äî if you look good, you feel good ‚Äî took her out to get ice cream, pushed her in her wheel chair outside every day to get her into the sunshine and took her to church almost every week,‚Äù she says.

At church, her mother was much like her old self, Nunn says. ‚ÄúTaking my mom to church gave me back my mom for a few hours each week,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúShe could enter the church confused, but when the worship music started and the preacher preached, it was like the Holy Spirit made the confusion dissipate and mom was present. It was so cool to watch.‚Äù

For anyone starting the caregiver journey, Nunn has plenty of advice. ‚ÄúAsk for help early on,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúTake pictures with your loved one as much as possible, record their voice in videos, have your loved one write letters to their children, grandchildren, friends before they are unable to express themselves.‚Äù

Though dementia eventually claimed her mother‚Äôs memory, Nunn says she never forgot her husband, Don Dixon, and her Savior, Jesus Christ. ‚ÄúShe talked about dad frequently and told others about her love for Jesus,‚Äù she says.

And that‚Äôs how she hopes people will remember her mom. ‚ÄúShe loved Jesus and trusted him completely, even in this diagnosis,‚Äù Nunn says. ‚ÄúAnd she loved her family.‚Äù

Story by County of Johnston
Republished with permission

item.description:
Aging shows up in the body long before we notice it in the mind. But the brain ages quietly, slowly, sometimes without any obvious sign until memory slips or focus blurs. Scientists have spent years trying to understand whether lifestyle choices can actually shape this timeline, whether everyday activities can nudge the brain toward resilience instead of decline.

A new study published in Nature Communications in October suggests the answer might lie in something surprisingly simple: creativity.

7 Daily habits to follow every night for a sharper brain

Researchers found that certain activities were linked to brains that looked younger than a person‚Äôs actual age. What stood out was how accessible these activities are; they‚Äôre not limited to artists or prodigies, but to anyone willing to immerse themselves in something imaginative. As study author Agust√≠n Ib√°√±ez, director of the Latin American Brain Health Institute at Universidad Adolfo Ib√°√±ez, put it, ‚ÄúThis is not just a solution for the da Vincis of the world. Anyone can benefit from having a creative hobby, not just geniuses or professional artists.‚Äù

Speaking about the modern pressures people live under, he added, ‚ÄúWe are living in a world full of stress, uncertainty and despair. Creating a little bubble through art or music can have a positive impact on your brain health.‚Äù

What the study found

The research team analyzed brain imaging data from 1,467 healthy participants, including tango dancers, musicians, visual artists and strategy video game players. To measure how fast or slow the brain was aging, they used computational ‚Äúbrain clocks‚Äù that estimate biological brain age versus chronological age.

Accelerated aging, where the brain appears older than the person, is often seen in people with psychiatric or neurological conditions. But this study looked at the opposite: what activities are linked to delayed brain aging?

All four creative and cognitively demanding pursuits studied showed strong association with younger-looking brains. People with higher skill levels or years of practice had even stronger results.

Even beginners weren‚Äôt left out. In one experiment, researchers trained 24 people to play StarCraft II, a strategic video game, for 30 hours over several weeks. A control group trained on Hearthstone, a more rigid, rule-based game. After the training period, only the StarCraft II group showed slower brain aging.

On the basis of the study, these are few activities that were most strongly associated with delayed brain aging.

Dancing

The strongest effect in the study came from highly skilled tango dancers, whose brains appeared, on average, seven years younger than their chronological age. Dance activates motor skills, rhythm, coordination, social connection and fast decision-making, creating a deep cognitive workout.

Playing music

Musicians also showed younger biological brain age. Whether it‚Äôs learning a new instrument or returning to an old one, the combination of melody, memory, timing and emotional processing seems to strengthen brain networks over time.

Visual art

Painting, drawing or any form of visual creation was linked to delayed brain aging. It‚Äôs not about talent; it‚Äôs about a process that keeps cognitive pathways active.

Strategy video games

Games like StarCraft II, which require planning, creativity and rapid problem-solving, were associated with younger-looking brains, even after just 30 hours of training.

Attending performances and exhibitions

Passive engagement matters too. Going to concerts, plays or museums for a few hours a week was associated with better memory and slower cognitive decline, according to Sonke‚Äôs 2022 study of older adults.

item.description:
Meghan Jenkins had her hands full with her toddler, Malachi. He was energetic and inquisitive, eager to explore the world around him. He loved anything to do with the Miami Dolphins and played constantly with dinosaurs and monster trucks. He was settling in at day care while Jenkins returned to work after taking a year off. Life was busy, but happy. ¬†

In March 2021, Jenkins noticed Malachi was tired and lethargic. He also had a lingering cough. One day, he threw up. When Jenkins changed his diaper, she found black stool. Immediately concerned, she and Malachi went straight to the emergency room.¬†

Things moved quickly then, Jenkins said. Malachi was "connected to all these cords." Someone said he might need a blood transfusion. Hours passed with no answers. Jenkins grew more scared by the minute. Finally, Malachi was admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit, where doctors performed a bone marrow biopsy.¬†

Finally, a doctor sat Jenkins down for the diagnosis: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia. She was told her little boy's life expectancy could be just two and a half to three more years.¬†

"In that moment, you question God. You ask him 'Why did this happen?'" Jenkins said. "I was so lost. This was my only child. I was young still, going through life, trying to figure things out. And then I had a big hit."¬†

What is acute lymphoblastic leukemia?¬†

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia, or ALL, is a rare cancer that starts in the bone marrow, according to the American Cancer Society's website. Only about 6,100 new cases of ALL are diagnosed a year, according to the American Cancer Society, with children under the age of 5 having the highest risk of developing the disease.¬†

ALL is a fast-growing cancer that results in the body producing immature white blood cells. Malachi's white blood cell count was more than 10 times higher than it should be. The white blood cells were crowding out healthy cells, weakening his immune system and making it impossible for his body to fight off infections.¬†

ALL can quickly spread throughout the body and affect the lymph nodes, liver, spleen and other organs, as well as the central nervous system. Because the cancer grows so quickly, immediate treatment is key.¬†

Malachi was already "quite sick" when he was diagnosed, said Dr. Julio Barredo, the director of pediatric cancer programs at Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center. She started Malachi on chemotherapy immediately.¬†

Treating acute lymphoblastic leukemia ¬†

For the first month of treatment, Malachi was hospitalized. The first weeks of chemotherapy are intense, so staying in the hospital is often safer, said pediatric hematologist Dr. Aditi Dhir. Malachi had side effects including nausea and fatigue. He regressed in his potty training. Jenkins needed to wear gloves to hold him because of his compromised immune system. The toddler milestones she'd expected to celebrate were nowhere to be seen.¬†

"There were days I didn't even think I was going to go on, but I had to," Jenkins said. "It was stressful. It was depressing, constantly being in there."¬†

Still, the chemotherapy was clearly helping Malachi, Dhir said. She recalled seeing him run around the PICU within a week of starting treatment. Barredo said that Malachi handled the chemotherapy "as well as anybody could have handled it given the circumstances."¬†

After the first month, Malachi continued chemotherapy at home. He took eight medications a day, Jenkins said, and spent several days a week in the hospital. Next came the "maintenance" phase, Barredo said. During this time, Malachi remained on oral medication and only needed to go to the hospital every few weeks, Dhir explained. The maintenance phase lasted for two years.¬†

Finally, in August 2023, "the storm blew over," Jenkins said. Malachi was able to ring the bell that signified the completion of cancer treatment.¬†

"You can't tell he ever had leukemia"¬†

Today, Malachi is a "very loving" 7-year-old who excels in school, takes gifted classes and regularly appears on the honor roll, Jenkins said. He still cheers for the Dolphins and plays with dinosaurs and trucks. He's become a big reader and loves to share fun facts.¬†

Most importantly, he is in remission. With acute lymphoblastic leukemia, the highest risk of relapse is within the first year of completing therapy, Barredo said. Malachi passed that milestone with flying colors. There's "some risk" of relapse in the second year, Barredo said, but Malachi and Jenkins marked that in August without incident. After two years, it "is quite unusual" for an ALL patient to relapse, Barredo said. Malachi has outperformed his initial prognosis, and the success of his treatment means "his life expectancy is like that of any other kid his age."¬†

"You look at him, you can't tell he ever had leukemia," Barredo said. "For all practical purposes, he is pretty much cured at this point in time. ... He'll be able to do whatever he wants to do."¬†

Malachi's immune system remains compromised, Jenkins said, but she hopes to build it up so can have a normal childhood going forward. The family is looking forward to "finally blossoming" after the years of treatment and trauma.¬†

"This whole process was very hard. It's still hard. I have moments sometimes where I'm in shock, like I don't believe we went through this or this even happened," Jenkins said. "But there is a brighter situation. Every situation doesn't have this outcome. But there are brighter outcomes. There are happier days than just being in the hospital and being sad."¬†

item.description:
"How often do you poop?" might sound like a very personal question, but your answer could reveal quite a lot about your overall health.

A study published in July 2024 investigated how often 1,425 people went number two, and compared those stats to their demographic, genetic, and health data.

The healthiest participants reported pooping once or twice a day ‚Äì a 'Goldilocks zone' of bowel movement frequency.

Pooping too often or too rarely were both associated with different underlying health issues, the team led by researchers at the Institute for Systems Biology (ISB) found.

Related: Something in Your Poop May Predict an Imminent Death

"This study shows how bowel movement frequency can influence all body systems, and how aberrant bowel movement frequency may be an important risk factor in the development of chronic diseases," says ISB microbiologist Sean Gibbons, the corresponding author of the report.

"These insights could inform strategies for managing bowel movement frequency, even in healthy populations, to optimize health and wellness."

Watch the video below for a summary:

The study investigated the bathroom habits of people who were "generally healthy" ‚Äì that is, with no history of kidney or gut issues like kidney disease, irritable bowel syndrome, or Crohn's disease.

Participants self-reported how often they dropped the kids off at the pool, and the researchers organized them into four categories: constipation for those reporting one or two bowel movements per week; low-normal for three to six movements per week; high-normal for one to three movements per day; and diarrhea for four or more watery stools per day.

The researchers also analyzed patients' blood metabolites and chemistry, their genetics, and the gut microbes present in their stool samples.

The team looked for possible associations between bowel movement frequency and these health markers, as well as other factors like their age and sex.

In general, those who reported less frequent bowel movements tended to be women, younger, and with a lower body mass index (BMI). But even accounting for these factors, people with constipation or diarrhea showed clear links to underlying health issues.

Bacteria usually found in the upper gastrointestinal tract were more common in stool samples from participants with diarrhea. Their blood samples, meanwhile, showed biomarkers associated with liver damage.

Stool samples from people with less frequent bowel movements had higher levels of bacteria associated with protein fermentation. This is a known hazard from constipation.

"If stool sticks around too long in the gut, microbes use up all of the available dietary fiber, which they ferment into beneficial short-chain fatty acids," says Johannes Johnson-Martinez, a bioengineer at ISB.

"After that, the ecosystem switches to fermentation of proteins, which produces several toxins that can make their way into the bloodstream."

Sure enough, some of these byproducts were found in these patients' blood samples. Particularly enriched was a metabolite called indoxyl-sulfate, a known product of protein fermentation that can damage the kidneys.

The team suggests the finding is potential evidence of a causal link between bowel movement frequency and overall health.

There is some hope that people can change their habits and, as a result, their health. Recent research suggests your gut microbiome can shift a lot faster than you might think.

For instance, a 2025 study from Germany, yet to undergo peer review, tracked inactive adults who began resistance training twice or three times a week. Those who gained the most strength showed changes in the makeup of their gut bacteria in just eight weeks.

These kinds of changes might help some people move out of the constipation or diarrhea categories and into a healthier bowel-movement range.

Those in the Goldilocks zone of pooping reported eating more fiber, drinking more water, and exercising more often. Their stool samples also showed high levels of bacteria associated with fermenting fiber.

A clinical trial published in 2025 by US researchers found that people with a lot of methane-producing microbes in their guts are especially efficient at turning dietary fiber into short-chain fatty acids.

This suggests that both the amount of fiber and the specific mix of microbes in an individual's gut are important, which explains why two people eating the same diet can experience different health outcomes.

Related: Here's How to Avoid Food Poisoning This Thanksgiving

Of course, everybody's found themselves at one extreme or the other at some point in their lives, after catching a stomach bug or eating too much cheese. But this study was looking at people's everyday routine, and reveals how our own version of 'normal' could hint at health issues we weren't aware of.

The research was published in the journal Cell Reports Medicine.

An earlier version of this article was published in July 2025.
item.author: ScienceAlert

item.description:
Cancer came crashing into Maria Pascale‚Äôs life like a high-speed car ‚Äî literally.

During a CT scan after a traumatic car accident in February 2018, Pascale was dealt another blow when doctors noticed a mass in her neck, in between the esophagus and thyroid gland. A biopsy later confirmed it was squamous cell carcinoma, snaking around her vocal cords.

‚ÄúI was really nervous,‚Äù said Pascale, who lives in Philadelphia.

Over the next seven years, she tried all of the conventional treatment options, but the cancer kept returning. Pascale assumed she would be sick forever. That is, until a new treatment developed at Rutgers Cancer Institute, New Jersey‚Äôs only National Cancer Institute-designated Comprehensive Cancer Center, and RWJBarnabas Health changed her life.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know if I was going to be alive. And now I have 14 months of being strong,‚Äù said Pascale, who has been in remission since September 2024. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm doing more exercise, I go to karate. Now I can do things.‚Äù

Losing hope and finding it again

The cancer diagnosis caught Pascale by surprise. She didn‚Äôt notice any symptoms. She also didn‚Äôt match the standard profile for head and neck cancer, which is twice as common among men and often diagnosed in people over age 50. Pascale, now 50, was diagnosed at 43 years old.

Head and neck cancer impacts thousands of people each year in the United States. In 2025, an estimated 72,680 people in the U.S. will receive a diagnosis of cancer of the oral cavity, pharynx, or larynx, the major types of head and neck cancer, according to the National Cancer Institute.

Alcohol and tobacco use are two of the most important risk factors for head and neck cancers. However, a large portion of new head and neck diagnoses are being driven by cancer-causing types of human papillomavirus, or HPV, according to an Oct. 30 article in the Bulletin of the American College of Surgeons.

Pascale was diagnosed with a type of HPV-related head and neck cancer. Within months of her diagnosis, Pascale underwent three surgeries to remove the cancerous mass in her neck, cut out parts of her tonsils and the back of her tongue, and take out her lymph nodes.

‚ÄúThe surgeries were really painful, especially the second one. My sister is strong, but that one was bad,‚Äù said Maria Durante, Pascale‚Äôs sister.

The surgeries were brutal, but they seemed effective at removing the cancer. Then, one day in 2021, Pascale began to have difficulty swallowing. It felt like food getting stuck in her throat. A CT scan revealed a mass around her esophagus. This time, Pascale said, she underwent chemotherapy and radiation.

Two years later, she learned the cancer had metastasized to the lungs. More chemotherapy followed, but it was less effective at shrinking her tumors. Then, at the start of 2024, Pascale developed an allergic reaction to her chemotherapy treatment. She felt defeated.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt have any hope because all of the traditional treatments, they were not working for me,‚Äù said Pascale.

That‚Äôs when her oncologist at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital mentioned a clinical trial at Rutgers Cancer Institute and RWJBarnabas Health that was using cellular therapy to treat advanced HPV-related cancers.

Cellular therapy has generated a lot of excitement in recent years, especially CAR T-cell therapy, which has proven to be successful in treating certain blood cancers. The therapy takes a patient‚Äôs cells and genetically engineers them to target and attack the cancer cells.

Dr. Christian Hinrichs, who leads the cell therapy program at Rutgers Cancer Institute, has been working for years on a similar treatment for other types of cancer. He developed a one-time cellular therapy for patients with metastatic HPV-associated cancers and the clinical trial has yielded promising results.

When Pascale got the treatment at Rutgers Cancer Institute in July 2024, she said that at first, ‚Äúit was really painful.‚Äù

‚ÄúI felt like I had pneumonia, it was horrible, but it was the cells working. That‚Äôs how I took it ‚Äî I‚Äôm feeling this way because the cells are working and killed the cancer," said Pascale.

Six out of 10 patients treated so far, including Pascale, have achieved substantial tumor shrinkage, according to the findings presented at the Society for Immunotherapy of Cancer Annual Meeting on Nov. 5‚Äì9.

‚ÄúAt an individual level it‚Äôs life-changing for these patients who‚Äôve had their cancers go away,‚Äù said Hinrichs, co-director of the Duncan and Nancy MacMillan Cancer Immunology and Metabolism Center of Excellence at Rutgers Cancer Institute and chief of the Section of Cancer Immunotherapy.

On a broader level, he added, the study offers hope that cellular therapy can be applied for the treatment of other cancers.

‚ÄúIt shows that this type of treatment approach with the one-time engineered T-cell therapy can cause complete responses in epithelial cancers, in these common cancers. And although we‚Äôre starting with HPV, it‚Äôs a foundation to build from,‚Äù said Hinrichs.

Now living in remission, Pascale encourages other cancer patients to never give up trying new treatment options. Just when she was feeling weary, the clinical trial came around.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs painful. It‚Äôs hard. But you have to be strong and try,‚Äù said Pascale.

item.description:
It‚Äôs the cooking oil Americans reach for every single day, often without a second thought. In fact, it is a staple in processed foods. A cooking oil commonly consumed in the United States could be fuelling the obesity crisis.

A recent experiment conducted at UC Riverside found that

America‚Äôs favourite cooking oil is linked to obesity

. The findings of the research are published in the

Journal of Lipid Research

.

5 Oils that should be consumed raw for potential health benefits

Soybean oil linked to obesity

The researchers found that soybean oil, which is widely consumed by Americans, significantly contributes to obesity, at least in mice. The researchers also explored the metabolic pathway behind weight gain in mice.

During the experiment, the researchers found that most mice on a high-fat diet rich in soybean oil gained significant weight. However, this oil had no impact on genetically engineered mice. Instead, they produced a slightly different form of a liver protein that influences hundreds of genes linked to fat metabolism. This protein also changes how the body processes linoleic acid, a major component of soybean oil.

‚ÄúThis may be the first step toward understanding why some people gain weight more easily than others on a diet high in soybean oil,‚Äù corresponding author Sonia Deol, a UCR biomedical scientist, said.

The researchers noted that both versions of the liver protein HNF4Œ± exist in humans; however, the alternative form is produced only under certain conditions, such as chronic illness or metabolic stress from fasting or alcoholic fatty liver. This variation, along with differences in age, sex, medications, and genetics, may help explain why some people gain weight, and others don‚Äôt, while consuming soybean oil.

This new experiment builds on previous work by UCR researchers

linking soybean oil to weight gain

. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve known since our 2015 study that soybean oil is more obesogenic than coconut oil. But now we have the clearest evidence yet that it‚Äôs not the oil itself, or even linoleic acid. It‚Äôs what the fat turns into inside the body,‚Äù Frances Sladek, a UCR professor of cell biology, said.

The linoleic acid in soybean oil is converted into molecules called oxylipins. Excessive consumption leads to increased amounts of oxylipins, which are linked with inflammation and fat accumulation.

Is soybean oil the villain?

Soybean oil is widely consumed in the US. In fact, a 2011 study published in the

American Journal of Clinical Nutrition

found that there has been a

five-fold increase in soybean oil consumption

in the past century, from about 2% of total calories to nearly 10%.

Though soybeans are excellent sources of plant-based protein and their oil contains no cholesterol, excessive consumption of linoleic acid may cause more harm than good. As soybean oil is a staple in ultra-processed foods, it may be fuelling chronic metabolic conditions.

The researchers also found that despite the lack of cholesterol in soybean oil, its consumption is still associated with higher cholesterol levels in mice.

‚ÄúSoybean oil isn‚Äôt inherently evil. But the quantities in which we consume it are triggering pathways our bodies didn‚Äôt evolve to handle,‚Äù Sladek said.

‚ÄúIt took 100 years from the first observed link between chewing tobacco and cancer to get warning labels on cigarettes. We hope it won‚Äôt take that long for society to recognise the link between excessive soybean oil consumption and negative health effects,‚Äù Sladek added.

Note: The information provided in this article is for educational purposes only and is not intended as medical advice. Always consult a qualified healthcare professional before starting any new medication or treatment, or before changing your diet or supplement regimen.

item.description:
Staff from Idaho Fish and Game‚Äôs Panhandle Regional Office operated a check station Nov. 16 along Interstate 90 near Fourth of July Pass.¬†

The purpose of the station was to monitor hunter compliance with Idaho‚Äôs wildlife laws and to evaluate whether big game harvested out of state or from an Idaho chronic wasting disease management zone was being transported in accordance with CWD regulations.

Like many other states, Idaho prohibits transporting or importing the spine or brain tissue of deer, elk and moose harvested in states where CWD has been detected. Nearly all of Idaho‚Äôs neighboring states ‚Äî and most states nationwide ‚Äî are currently CWD-positive.

While the recent check station represents only a brief snapshot in time, Fish and Game staff observed that compliance with CWD-related transport rules was very low. Chronic wasting disease is a fatal neurological disease that poses a significant risk to Idaho‚Äôs big game herds,¬†

Hunters who pursue big game outside Idaho and plan to bring any parts into or through the state are encouraged to review Idaho‚Äôs legal transport requirements by visiting the CWD webpage on the Idaho Fish and Game website. Hunters who pursue big game within Idaho‚Äôs CWD management zones should also take time to understand the zone-specific rules and requirements before heading into the field.

Idaho law authorizes Fish and Game to operate check stations to enforce wildlife regulations and collect biological data that supports wildlife management. All hunters, anglers and trappers ‚Äî with or without game ‚Äî are required to stop when encountering an official Fish and Game check station.

‚Äî Idaho Department of Fish and Game

item.description:
Heart rhythms and pace give critical insights into cardiovascular health. The rhythms of your heartbeat can reveal a lot, even warn you about your conditions. Just like how irregular heartbeats indicate conditions like arrhythmia. Just like irregular heartbeats can indicate arrhythmia, a slow heartbeat is not always normal either; it could be a sign of a concerning condition called bradycardia.

ALSO READ: Are you at risk of heart disease? Study reveals eating these foods could reduce your risk of irregular heartbeat

To better understand the warning signs, HT Lifestyle reached out to Dr Dilip Kumar, senior interventional cardiologist and device specialist, Manipal Hospital at EM Bypass in Kolkata.

Explaining what bradycardia is, Dr Dilip Kumar said, ‚ÄúIt is a condition where your heart consistently beats slower than 60 beats per minute (bpm).‚Äù As per the cardiologist, this is alarming because it means your heart might not be pumping oxygen-rich blood enough to your body, impacting energy and overall health.

Dr Kumar further elaborated that when the heart's electrical system, which controls its rhythm, does not work properly, the heart can beat too slowly. While a slow heartbeat can be normal for athletes, for others it may signal an underlying health problem that needs attention.

Who should be careful?

A slow heartbeat can happen to anyone; some people need to be particularly cautious. Dr Kumar, "Certain groups are at higher risk, including older adults, individuals with existing heart conditions, diabetes, or kidney disease, and those taking certain medications.‚Äù So if you fall into any of the mentioned groups, monitoring your heart rate and consulting a doctor regularly would help to detect bradycardia and prevent complications such as dizziness, fatigue, or fainting.

Can it be prevented?

So, can this be prevented? As per the cardiologist, not all causes of a slow heartbeat can be avoided, but you can lower your risk by taking care of your heart.

He added, "While not all causes are preventable, maintaining a heart-healthy lifestyle through regular exercise, a balanced diet, stress management, and routine medical check-ups can significantly reduce your risk and support overall heart health.‚Äù

5 warning signs which indicates that indicate your slow heartbeat could be bradycardia

Dr Kumar listed these 5 signs which may mean you have bradycardia and require a doctor visit:

  1. Persistent fatigue and weakness: Feeling drained, even after rest, can signal that your heart isn't delivering enough oxygen.
  2. Dizziness or light-headedness: Insufficient blood flow to the brain due to a slow heart rate can cause these sensations.
  3. Fainting or near-fainting spells: A sudden, significant drop in heart rate can lead to loss of consciousness.
  4. Shortness of breath, especially during activity: Your heart struggles to meet oxygen demands, causing breathlessness with minimal exertion.
  5. Chest pain or discomfort: This can indicate your heart muscle isn't receiving enough oxygen.

Note to readers: This article is for informational purposes only and not a substitute for professional medical advice. Always seek the advice of your doctor with any questions about a medical condition.

item.title: ÂÜ∑ÂÜªÈù¢ÂåÖÂ¶Ç‰Ωï‰ΩøÈù¢ÂåÖÂØπË°ÄÁ≥ñÊéßÂà∂ÂíåËÇ†ÈÅìÂÅ•Â∫∑Êõ¥ÂÅ•Â∫∑-Âç∞Â∫¶Êó∂Êä•
item.description:
Bread sits at the centre of many winter meals, yet few people realise that the way it is stored can subtly shape its nutritional behaviour. For many households, freezing bread is simply a practical step to reduce waste during colder months when groceries last longer and consumption patterns shift. Recent discussions among clinicians and nutrition researchers have highlighted that freezing may also influence how the body processes carbohydrates. In a

popular reel, Dr Kunal Sood explained

that freezing alters the structure of starch in ways that change how the digestive system responds to it. This has prompted renewed interest in understanding whether a basic habit like freezing bread can support healthier metabolic patterns.

Hidden health benefits of freezing bread

Dr Kunal Sood describes the process clearly, saying, ‚ÄúFreezing your bread doesn‚Äôt just keep it from going stale, it can actually make it a little healthier. Here‚Äôs how. When bread is frozen and then defrosted, some of the starches go through a process called retrogradation. That‚Äôs when part of the starch structure reorganises and turns into what‚Äôs known as resistant starch.‚Äù Resistant starch behaves differently from the rapidly digested starches found in freshly baked bread. In his words, ‚ÄúResistant starch acts more like fibre than sugar. Your body digests it more slowly, which leads to steadier blood sugar levels and less of a spike after eating.‚Äù

Five Effective Ways to Detoxify Your Gut Health

This explanation aligns with findings from a controlled trial

published in Journal of Preventative and Complementary Medicine

, which examined how freezing and reheating white bread affected the glycaemic response of healthy individuals. The researchers reported that freezing and then defrosting reduced post meal blood glucose spikes by up to 30 percent compared with fresh bread. As Dr Sood states, ‚ÄúOne study even found that freezing and then defrosting white bread reduced post meal blood sugar spikes by up to 30 percent, compared to eating it fresh.‚Äù These effects offer a foundation for understanding the key benefits, which include better digestion and metabolic balance, antioxidant protection and immunity support, a more stable blood sugar response, improved gut microbiome function and higher natural energy levels.

The key health effects linked to freezing bread:
  • Supports digestion
  • Boosts immunity
  • Stabilizes blood sugar
  • Improves gut health
  • Supports better daily energy

1. Better digestion and metabolic balance through resistant starch formation

When bread is exposed to freezing temperatures, the starch molecules gradually reorganise into a form that the body breaks down more slowly. This change means the digestive tract expends less effort managing sudden glucose surges, which often strain metabolic pathways during colder seasons when heavier meals are common. The presence of resistant starch encourages a steadier digestive rhythm, allowing nutrients to be absorbed at a smoother pace. Many individuals find that foods containing resistant starch contribute to prolonged satiety and more consistent digestive comfort, particularly when eaten during winter months when fluctuations in eating patterns tend to be more pronounced.

2. Antioxidant protection and immunity boost influenced by slower digestion

Slower carbohydrate digestion affects how antioxidants and micronutrients are released and absorbed. Winter diets often rely on preserved, reheated or starchy foods, which sometimes offer limited micronutrient density. Bread that has undergone freezing and retrogradation releases its sugars at a slower rate, which helps maintain more balanced cellular activity. This supports the immune system indirectly, because stable metabolic conditions improve the body‚Äôs capacity to regulate inflammation and oxidative stress. Although bread is not a primary antioxidant source, its altered digestibility helps regulate processes that protect immune cells from excessive metabolic strain.

3. More stable blood sugar response supported by clinical findings

A central benefit, articulated by both Dr Sood and the referenced study, is the measurable reduction in post meal blood glucose spikes. The shift toward resistant starch means the carbohydrate behaves more like dietary fibre, resulting in a gradual rise in glucose rather than a rapid surge. This is particularly relevant in winter, when many people rely on toast or warm sandwiches as quick energy sources. A gentler glycaemic response helps support concentration, appetite control and overall metabolic stability throughout the day. As Dr Sood adds, ‚ÄúIf you toast it after freezing, the effect becomes even stronger,‚Äù suggesting that reheating may amplify this stabilising influence.

4. Improved gut microbiome function through increased resistant starch intake

Resistant starch plays a recognised role in feeding beneficial gut bacteria, which rely on fermentable fibres to produce short chain fatty acids. These compounds support colon health, enhance nutrient absorption and contribute to balanced immune responses. Dr Sood highlights this when he says, ‚ÄúThat slower digestion helps not just for glucose control but also supports gut health since resistant starch feeds the beneficial bacteria in your colon.‚Äù During winter, when digestive sluggishness and irregular meal timing are common, foods that nourish the microbiome can help maintain smoother digestive behaviour and improve overall wellbeing.

5. Higher natural energy levels linked to steadier carbohydrate release

Energy fluctuations in cold weather often reflect inconsistent glucose patterns influenced by refined carbohydrates. Freezing bread adjusts the structure of its starch in a way that creates a more gradual energy supply. Instead of a quick burst followed by fatigue, the body receives a sustained release that supports alertness and endurance throughout daily activities. This makes frozen then toasted bread a practical winter staple for individuals who rely on predictable energy, whether for work, study or exercise in colder conditions.

What eating soaked raisins daily can do for your bones, digestion, and immunity this winter

item.description:
During winter, maintaining balanced nutrition is particularly relevant due to colder temperatures, reduced sunlight exposure, and shifts in daily activity. Traditional practices in many households encourage consuming soaked raisins, or kishmish, on a daily basis, a habit increasingly supported by modern nutritional science. Soaked raisins are rich in fibre, essential minerals, antioxidants, and natural sugars, making them a compact source of nutrients that can support energy levels, digestive function, and immune resilience. By integrating these nutrient-dense dried fruits into daily meals, individuals can address seasonal nutritional gaps, promote cardiovascular and bone health, and provide their bodies with steady energy throughout the colder months. Scientific understanding now validates these traditional practices and explains the physiological benefits.

Benefits of eating soaked raisins

Scientific research

published in Nutrients

indicates that consuming soaked raisins regularly offers multiple advantages during the colder months. Raisins are an abundant source of dietary fibre and bioactive compounds, which aid digestion and contribute to moderating blood glucose levels. They also contain key minerals such as iron, calcium, and boron, which are important for oxygen transport, bone density, and joint health.

Additionally, the phenolic compounds present in raisins function as antioxidants, helping reduce oxidative stress and support immune function. Regular intake has also been linked to favourable cardiovascular outcomes, including improved lipid profiles and reduced blood pressure. These combined properties make soaked raisins particularly valuable as a winter dietary inclusion.

Health benefits of Raisins

Eating soaked raisins helps:
  • Aid digestion and metabolism
  • Support bone strength and blood health
  • Support immunity with antioxidants
  • Stabilize blood sugar

1. Digestive and metabolic balance

One of the primary benefits of raisins is their high dietary fibre content, which promotes healthy bowel function and supports overall digestive regularity. Soaked raisins, which absorb water during preparation, become softer and easier to digest, allowing nutrients to be absorbed more efficiently. The soluble fibre and natural sugars in raisins provide a steady release of energy, avoiding sharp post-meal spikes in blood glucose that are commonly associated with refined or processed snacks. Scientific studies demonstrate that raisins have a low-to-moderate glycaemic index, which can help maintain metabolic stability throughout the day. During winter, when individuals may consume heavier meals and engage in less physical activity, this property of raisins becomes particularly advantageous, supporting both digestive comfort and sustained energy levels.

2. Mineral content for bone and circulatory support

Raisins are rich in minerals that are crucial for maintaining health during winter. Iron, for example, is essential for the production of haemoglobin and the transport of oxygen in the blood, helping to sustain energy and reduce fatigue that may be exacerbated by colder weather and reduced activity. Calcium and boron are important for bone health, with boron facilitating calcium absorption and utilisation, particularly during months when vitamin D synthesis from sunlight is limited. Consuming soaked raisins regularly provides a natural source of these minerals, supporting bone density, joint function, and overall circulatory health. Additionally, the iron content in raisins contributes to maintaining haemoglobin levels, which in turn supports cardiovascular performance, energy metabolism, and general wellbeing during periods of reduced outdoor exposure.

3. Antioxidants for immunity and oxidative stress

Raisins contain phenolic and polyphenolic compounds that act as antioxidants, helping the body neutralise free radicals and reduce oxidative stress. Winter conditions, including lower sunlight, cold stress, and higher exposure to seasonal pathogens, can increase oxidative stress and challenge immune function. The antioxidants present in raisins support cellular defence mechanisms, helping to maintain tissue integrity and reduce the impact of oxidative damage. These compounds also contribute to cardiovascular protection by preserving vascular health and promoting favourable lipid profiles. By incorporating soaked raisins into the daily diet, individuals provide their bodies with a natural source of antioxidants that support immunity, reduce inflammation, and contribute to overall physiological resilience during the colder months.

4. Cardiovascular wellness and glycaemic control

Regular consumption of raisins has been associated with improvements in cardiovascular and metabolic health. Clinical trials indicate that consuming raisins before meals can reduce postprandial glucose levels compared with calorie-matched processed snacks. Observational studies further suggest that regular raisin intake may lower systolic blood pressure and improve low-density lipoprotein cholesterol levels. These cardiovascular and metabolic benefits are particularly relevant in winter, when sedentary habits, heavier meals, and seasonal changes in activity can increase the risk of elevated blood pressure or impaired glucose regulation. Incorporating soaked raisins into daily routines provides a simple, natural means to support heart health, maintain steady blood glucose levels, and contribute to overall metabolic stability during the colder season.

How to consume soaked raisins

For maximum benefit, raisins should be soaked in water for several hours or overnight, which softens their texture and improves digestibility. A recommended portion of 80‚Äì90 grams, roughly half a cup, delivers concentrated nutrients without excessive caloric intake. Soaked raisins can be eaten directly in the morning, added to breakfast cereals, yogurt, or smoothies, or incorporated into baked dishes and winter recipes. Regular inclusion in a balanced diet, alongside vegetables, whole grains, and protein, ensures that their fibre, minerals, antioxidants, and natural sugars complement overall nutritional intake. By consuming soaked raisins consistently, individuals can support digestion, cardiovascular health, immune function, and energy balance throughout the winter months in a convenient and practical manner.

item.description:
• Type 2 diabetes, which occurs when the body stops responding to insulin, the hormone that controls blood glucose levels, is becoming increasingly common.
  • Before type 2 diabetes develops, many people have blood glucose levels that are higher than normal, a condition called prediabetes that is usually symptom-free.
  • Now, an Indian study has found that if people take steps to combat prediabetes within 2 years of diagnosis, they can prevent it progressing to type 2 diabetes.

Diabetes, a condition in which the body cannot control blood glucose levels, is a leading cause of death and disability worldwide.

In 2021, 529 million people had diabetes, and the number is forecast to rise to 1.31 billion by 2050. Of these, some 96% have type 2 diabetes, a condition that is often linked to lifestyle factors, such as poor diet, overweight and obesity, or lack of exercise.

Now, an Indian study, published in The Journal of Diabetes & Metabolic Disorders, has found that if people take steps to control their prediabetes within 2 years of diagnosis, they have a good chance of preventing it progressing to type 2 diabetes.

Jack Ogden, MBChB, BSc, LLM, IBLM, MRCGP, a primary care physician with a specialization in diabetes, from The Lagom Clinic, Bristol, United Kingdom, who was not involved in this research, commented to Medical News Today that:

‚ÄúThe study employs a well-constructed retrospective cohort using 10 years of electronic medical record data from a closed urban population. The use of multi-state modeling is robust, with transitions aligning well with other cohort studies. However, there are some limitations to consider, such as reliance on opportunistic testing, potential selection bias, and limited generalizability due to the specific population studied. This study was only in a small area of India with its own culture and food preferences, making its less generalizable to many other people.‚Äù

However, a few people are diagnosed following symptoms that may include:

  • increased appetite
  • unexplained weight loss/weight gain
  • high body mass index (BMI)
  • weakness
  • fatigue
  • sweating
  • blurred vision
  • slow healing cuts or bruises
  • recurrent skin infections/gum bleeding.

Because prediabetes is usually symptom-free, Ogden advised that ‚Äúit‚Äôs crucial to focus on risk factors like being overweight, having a family history of diabetes, or conditions such as hypertension.‚Äú

‚ÄúTesting is generally recommended from the age of 35, or earlier for individuals with these risk factors. For higher-risk populations, such as South Asians, earlier testing from around age 25 may be appropriate,‚Äù he told MNT.

For most, the condition will be detected by a blood glucose test ‚Äî the hemoglobin A1c, or HbA1c test. This simple blood test shows average blood glucose levels over the preceding 3 months, with the results given as a percentage, as follows:

  • normal blood sugar ‚Äî below 5.7%
  • prediabetes ‚Äî between 5.7 and 6.4%
  • type 2 diabetes ‚Äî above 6.4%.

Type 2 diabetes is far more common in people who have had prediabetes than in those who have normal blood glucose levels, so lifestyle changes that reverse prediabetes are key to preventing it progressing to the more serious condition.

‚ÄúPreventing progression to type 2 diabetes requires prompt lifestyle modifications. Aiming for 5-10% weight loss, engaging in at least 150 minutes of physical activity per week, and focusing on a diet rich in whole grains, vegetables, and lean proteins can be impactful. Addressing lifestyle factors such as sleep quality, stress management, and smoking cessation is also vital.‚Äù

‚Äì Jack Ogden, MBChB, BSc, LLM, IBLM, MRCGP

Studies have shown that several lifestyle interventions are effective in reversing prediabetes in adults. These include:

  • weight loss ‚Äî keeping to a healthy weight (BMI of less than 25) or, if overweight, losing 5-7% of your body weight
  • increasing your physical activity ‚Äî one study found that just 150 minutes of exercise a week could bring blood glucose back to healthy levels
  • following a healthy diet, such as the Mediterranean or DASH diet, which focuses on complex, fiber-rich carbohydrates and healthy unsaturated fats, while restricting sugars, processed foods, and saturated fats
  • getting adequate sleep.

‚ÄúNutrition (whole foods, balanced intake, moderated caloric load), mindful movement, and lifestyle stewardship aren‚Äôt just wellness buzzwords but proven intervention tools,‚Äù advised Barbara Eichorst, MS, RD, CDCES, vice president of health care programs at the American Diabetes Association, likewise not involved in the recent study.

This study is not alone in suggesting that lifestyle modifications can be very effective, as Eichorst emphasized:

‚ÄúResults from the landmark Diabetes Prevention Program show that individuals at high risk for type 2 diabetes who engaged in a structured lifestyle-change program like modest weight loss (about 7% of body weight) plus about 150 minutes per week of physical activity, reduced their risk of developing type 2 diabetes by 58% over three years, compared with placebo.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs more,‚Äù she added, ‚Äúthese benefits endure. Long-term follow-up demonstrated that the lifestyle intervention continued to delay onset of diabetes and reduced long-term incidence over 10 to 15 years.‚Äù

‚ÄúThese findings powerfully affirm that through intentional, consistent choices around nutrition, physical activity, and weight management, many people with prediabetes can significantly delay progression to type 2 diabetes,‚Äù said Eichorst.

The longer a person has had prediabetes, the harder it is to reverse it, so Ogden advised that taking steps as soon as prediabetes is diagnosed is key.

‚ÄúThe study emphasizes the importance of timely action, particularly within the first 2-3 years of a prediabetes diagnosis, as this period is the most effective window for reversal,‚Äù he pointed out.

‚ÄúIt also underscores that, despite healthcare accessibility, approximately 30% of individuals with prediabetes progress to diabetes within a decade, whereas up to 60% revert in the early stages. This highlights the potential for targeted, early interventions to yield significant benefits,‚Äù added Ogden.

-Health Minister urges persons to get tested

Given the rise in HIV cases, Minister of Health, Dr Frank Anthony, yesterday appealed to persons to know their HIV status by accessing his ministry‚Äôs free at-home HIV self-testing kits, as he announced that Guyana last year reported 449 new cases and the Caribbean some 15,000.

‚ÄúIn the Caribbean 340,000 are living with HIV and over the last year we would have had about 15,000 new infections. In the past year here in Guyana, we would have diagnosed at least 449 new infections,‚Äù Dr. Anthony said as the Ministry of Health yesterday launched planned activities for the month of December with World AIDS Day globally recognised on December 1.¬† The Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) can result in Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) and death.

The Minister of Health emphasised that many of the new cases were preventable if persons would access the information and ‚Äúunderstand how to prevent these infections.‚Äù
